name: Circle Mobility
setup: Place 4 cones in a circle, about 5 meters apart
Put one player in the center with a ball
Have other players stand at each cone
Make sure everyone has enough space to move
execution: Center player passes to any cone player
Receive the pass back and pass to next cone
Keep the ball moving around the circle
Start slowly, then speed up as you warm up
Switch the center player every minute
coachingPoints: Use the inside of your foot for accurate passes
Call for the ball so your teammate knows you're ready
Keep your body loose and relaxed
Focus on good first touches
Encourage teammates with positive words
visualDescription: Draw: 4 cones in a circle, 1 player in center

name: Dynamic Running Line
setup: Set up 3-4 cones in a straight line
Space them about 10 meters apart
Line up all players at the starting cone
Make sure the path is clear and safe
execution: Jog to the first cone doing high knees
At each cone, do a different movement (butt kicks, side shuffle, etc.)
Walk back to recover between runs
Do 2-3 rounds with different movements
Stay light on your feet the whole time
coachingPoints: Keep your movements controlled, not sloppy
Breathe normally and don't hold your breath
Listen to your body as it warms up
Stretch any tight muscles gently
Have fun with different movement patterns
visualDescription: Draw: 3-4 cones in a line forming a track

name: Two Players Passing & Stretch
setup: Find a partner and grab one ball
Stand facing each other about 5-7 meters apart
Make sure you have plenty of room around you
Both players should be ready to move
execution: Pass the ball back and forth with your partner
After each pass, do a gentle leg stretch
Try hamstring stretches, quad stretches, and calf raises
Keep passing while you stretch
Switch legs every few passes
coachingPoints: Make accurate passes so your partner can stretch safely
Don't stretch too hard - just gentle movements
Talk to your partner and work together
Keep the ball moving even during stretches
Smile and encourage each other
visualDescription: Draw: 2 players facing each other, ball between them

name: Ladder Steps
setup: Set up a speed ladder or make 6 squares with cones
Each square should be about one step wide
Have players line up at one end
Show them the pattern before they start
execution: Start with simple one-foot-per-square steps
Then try two feet in each square
Next, try side-to-side patterns
Increase your speed as you get comfortable
Walk back and go again
coachingPoints: Quick feet are more important than big steps
Look ahead, not down at your feet
Stay on the balls of your feet
Keep your knees slightly bent
Challenge yourself with new patterns
visualDescription: Draw: 6 small squares in a row (cone ladder)

name: Opening Hips Drill
setup: Mark a straight line with cones about 10 meters long
Give each player their own line to work on
Show the proper hip opening technique
Make sure there's space between players
execution: Walk forward and step out to the side with one leg
Open your hip outward like opening a door
Return to center and step with the other leg
Keep alternating sides as you move forward
Do 2-3 rounds up and back
coachingPoints: Focus on opening your hips wide
This movement helps you change direction quickly
Keep your upper body steady
Don't rush - quality over speed
Feel the stretch in your inner thighs
visualDescription: Draw: Player with lateral step arrows

name: Short Sprints 10m
setup: Place two cones exactly 10 meters apart
Make several lanes if you have many players
Check that the running surface is safe
Have players start at the same cone
execution: Sprint as fast as you can to the far cone
Touch the cone and jog slowly back
Take a few breaths and go again
Do 5 sprints total
Push yourself a little more each time
coachingPoints: Drive your arms to help you run faster
Push off hard from your back foot
Sprint at about 70-80% speed during warmup
Jogging back helps your muscles recover
You should feel energized, not exhausted
visualDescription: Draw: 2 points 10m apart with arrow

name: Wall Pass 1-2
setup: Set up two cones about 15 meters apart
One player at each cone - one is the 'wall'
The moving player starts with the ball
Mark the area where the return pass should go
execution: Pass the ball to your partner (the wall)
Immediately sprint forward into space
Your partner passes the ball back to you in front
Control the ball and repeat
Switch roles after 5-10 passes
coachingPoints: Time your run after you pass
The 'wall' should pass the ball first-time if possible
Call for the ball so your partner knows where you are
This is how you beat defenders in a game
Practice with both feet
visualDescription: Draw: Player passes to wall (partner), receives return pass

name: Triangle Passing 3 Players
setup: Place 3 cones in a triangle shape
Make each side about 8-10 meters long
Put one player at each cone
Start with one ball
execution: Pass the ball clockwise around the triangle
After you pass, be ready to receive from the other side
After a minute, switch to counterclockwise
Try to keep a steady rhythm
Add a second ball once you're comfortable
coachingPoints: Pass to your teammate's front foot
Use proper passing technique every time
Move your feet to receive the ball properly
Communicate with your teammates
Keep your head up to see the whole triangle
visualDescription: Draw: Triangle shape with 3 players, arrows clockwise

name: Square Passing 4 Corners
setup: Make a square with 4 cones about 10 meters apart
Place one or two players at each corner
Start with one ball at any corner
Make sure everyone knows the pattern
execution: Pass diagonally across the square
After you pass, follow your pass to that corner
The next player receives, then passes diagonally
Keep the pattern going smoothly
Try not to let the ball stop
coachingPoints: Your pass should be firm but accurate
Move quickly after you pass
Call out the receiver's name
Control the ball with your first touch
This teaches you to move after passing in games
visualDescription: Draw: Square with 4 players, diagonal arrows

name: One Touch Passing Line
setup: Have players form a single line
Coach or target player stands 8-10 meters away
First player in line has a ball
Set up a return path to the back of the line
execution: First player passes to the coach with one touch
Coach passes back immediately
Player controls and goes to the back of the line
Next player goes right away
Keep the drill moving quickly
coachingPoints: Strike through the center of the ball
Plant your standing foot next to the ball
Follow through toward your target
This prepares you for quick game situations
Stay focused even when waiting in line
visualDescription: Draw: Line of players, arrow to coach/target

name: Pass and Follow
setup: Create 3 stations in a line, about 12 meters apart
Put several players at the first two stations
One player at the third station
Start with 2 balls at the first station
execution: Pass from station 1 to station 2, then follow your pass
Station 2 receives, passes to station 3, and follows
Station 3 passes back to station 1 and follows
Keep the pattern going continuously
Control every ball before passing
coachingPoints: Don't run before you pass - pass first
Run at good speed to the next station
Be ready to receive as soon as you arrive
Keep your passes on the ground
This is how football should flow
visualDescription: Draw: 3 players in line, arrow shows pass and movement

name: Pass, Control, Turn
setup: Partner up with one ball per pair
Stand about 10 meters apart facing each other
Mark turning space behind each player
Make sure you have room to turn safely
execution: Receive the pass from your partner
Take a good first touch to the side
Turn with the ball to face your partner
Pass back and they do the same
Alternate turning left and right
coachingPoints: Check over your shoulder before the ball arrives
Use the inside or outside of your foot to turn
Your first touch sets up everything else
Turn away from imaginary pressure
In games, this move creates space
visualDescription: Draw: Player receives ball, turn arrow shown

name: Gate Passing
setup: Create 4-6 small gates using pairs of cones
Make each gate about 2 meters wide
Spread them around a playing area
Partners start on opposite sides with one ball
execution: Pass the ball through any gate to your partner
Partner controls and passes back through a different gate
Count how many successful gate passes you make
Try to hit all the gates
Challenge yourselves to beat your score
coachingPoints: Aim for the center of the gate
Use the right amount of power
Look before you pass to pick the best gate
Celebrate when you're accurate
This improves your passing precision
visualDescription: Draw: 2 cones forming gate, arrow through them

name: Long Pass Target
setup: Mark two areas about 25-30 meters apart
Create a target zone at one end (use cones)
Partner up - one at each end
Need several balls to keep the drill flowing
execution: Strike a long pass toward your partner's zone
Partner controls the ball and passes back
Focus on hitting the target area
Try different techniques - lofted and driven passes
Count how many land in the target
coachingPoints: For long passes, lean back slightly and strike under the ball
Follow through high for lofted passes
Use your laces for power and distance
Watch the ball all the way to your foot
Long passes are important for switching play
visualDescription: Draw: Long distance with target zone marked

name: Zigzag Cones
setup: Place 5-6 cones in a zigzag pattern
Space them about 2 meters apart
Create multiple lanes if you have many players
Each player needs a ball
execution: Dribble through the cones using small touches
Weave in and out of each cone
Use both feet as you go
At the end, turn around and come back
Try to go faster each time
coachingPoints: Keep the ball close to your feet
Look up between touches to see where you're going
Use the inside and outside of both feet
Stay balanced with knees slightly bent
Good dribbling takes practice - keep trying
visualDescription: Draw: Snake/zigzag pattern of cones

name: Slalom + Finish
setup: Set up 4-5 cones in a slalom pattern
Place a goal or target at the end
Make a line of players with balls at the start
Have someone collect balls after shots
execution: Dribble through the cones quickly
After the last cone, take 1-2 touches toward goal
Shoot to score
Collect your ball and go to the back of the line
Focus on both dribbling and shooting
coachingPoints: Don't just dribble - be ready to shoot
Look up at the goal before you shoot
Place your shot, don't just blast it
This is what happens in real games
Strikers need to dribble and finish
visualDescription: Draw: Slalom pattern ending at goal

name: Two Balls Dribble
setup: Each player gets two balls
Mark out a safe dribbling area with cones
Make sure players have plenty of space
Start in a smaller area, expand as they improve
execution: Dribble both balls at the same time
Use one foot on each ball
Try to keep them close together
Move around the area without losing control
This is really challenging - laugh when you mess up
coachingPoints: This drill is super hard - that's okay
It improves your coordination with one ball too
Use very small touches
Look ahead, trust your feet
Even professionals find this tricky
visualDescription: Draw: Player with 2 balls

name: 1v0 Change Direction
setup: Mark a rectangular area about 15x10 meters
Each player has their own ball
Coach stands where everyone can see
Make sure the area is open and safe
execution: Dribble around the area at medium speed
When coach calls 'left' or 'right', change direction
Use moves like cuts, turns, or step-overs
Keep your head up to hear the coach
React as quickly as you can
coachingPoints: Push the ball ahead with the outside of your foot
Cut the ball with the inside to change direction
Explode into your new direction
Keep the ball under control even when you turn
Changing direction beats defenders
visualDescription: Draw: Arrows showing left and right changes

name: Rollover & Go
setup: Set up pairs of cones to act as defenders
Space them about 5 meters apart
Players line up with balls at the start
Show the rollover move before starting
execution: Dribble toward the cone
Roll the bottom of your foot over the ball
Drag it to the side and accelerate past the cone
Practice with both feet
Go back and forth several times
coachingPoints: Sell the fake by looking one way first
Roll your foot over the ball smoothly
Explode away after the move
This move creates space in 1v1 situations
Messi uses this move all the time
visualDescription: Draw: Ball with circular arrow indicating rollover

name: Dribble to Coach
setup: Set up a simple slalom pattern of 3-4 cones
Coach stands at the end with no ball
Players line up at the start with balls
Keep extra balls ready for quick rotation
execution: Dribble through the pattern toward the coach
When you reach the coach, pass the ball to them
Coach passes back to you
Control the return pass and dribble back
Next player goes when you're halfway through
coachingPoints: Combine your dribbling and passing skills
Make an accurate pass to the coach
Be ready for the return pass
Say 'thank you' to the coach
Keep the drill moving quickly
visualDescription: Draw: Slalom pattern then pass to coach

name: Simple Finish from Pass
setup: Set up a goal (or two cones as a goal)
Create a passing station to the side, about 10 meters away
Line of shooters stands centrally in front of goal
Passers have several balls ready
execution: Passer sends the ball to the shooter's feet
Shooter takes one touch to set up
Shooter strikes the ball toward goal
Collect the ball and switch roles
Practice shooting with both feet
coachingPoints: Your first touch should set up your shot
Keep your shot low and on target
Strike through the center of the ball
Place your standing foot next to the ball
Celebrate your goals - but stay focused
visualDescription: Draw: Pass from side, goal straight ahead

name: Turn & Shoot
setup: Place a cone about 12 meters from goal
Shooter stands at the cone with back to goal
Passer stands behind the shooter with balls
A goalkeeper or target makes it realistic
execution: Passer plays ball to the shooter's feet
Shooter receives with back to goal
Turn quickly toward goal
Shoot within 2 touches
Rotate positions after 5 shots each
coachingPoints: Check your shoulder to see where the goal is
Take your first touch away from pressure
Turn into space, not toward defenders
Shoot quickly before imaginary defenders recover
Strikers must be good at turning and shooting
visualDescription: Draw: Player back to goal, turn arrow shown

name: Rebound Finish
setup: Set up a goal with a goalkeeper or wall
Shooter starts about 15 meters from goal
Have lots of balls ready
Mark where rebounds usually land
execution: Take your first shot on goal
Immediately follow your shot
If the ball rebounds, shoot again quickly
Keep shooting until you score or ball goes out
Get ready for the next turn
coachingPoints: Always follow your shot in case of rebounds
Stay alert and ready for second chances
Many goals come from rebounds in real games
Keep your shots on target to create rebounds
Be first to the ball - be hungry for goals
visualDescription: Draw: Shot, bounce back arrow, follow-up shot

name: 1v1 vs Cone GK
setup: Place a goal with a cone in the middle as a keeper
Mark a starting point about 10 meters from goal
Players line up with balls at the start
Have someone collect balls from behind the goal
execution: Dribble toward the goal at speed
As you get close, pick a side (left or right of cone)
Shoot past the cone-keeper
Try to score every time
Next player goes when the shooter is halfway
coachingPoints: Make your decision early - left or right
Keep the ball close as you approach
Shoot with confidence to the side you chose
This teaches you to finish in 1v1 situations
Imagine the cone is a real keeper moving around
visualDescription: Draw: Goal with cone representing keeper

name: Cross & Finish
setup: Mark a wing position on the side of the field
Set up a goal with a goalkeeper if possible
Striker starts near the penalty spot
Wingers line up with balls on the side
execution: Winger dribbles toward the goal line
Winger crosses the ball into the box
Striker runs to meet the cross
Striker finishes with head or foot
Rotate roles every 5 crosses
coachingPoints: Wingers should look up before crossing
Put the cross where the striker can reach it
Strikers should attack the ball, not wait
Time your run to meet the ball at full speed
Crosses lead to many goals in real games
visualDescription: Draw: Wing position, cross arrow to box

name: Shoot after Dribble
setup: Create a slalom of 4-5 cones leading to goal
Place the last cone about 16 meters from goal
Set up a goal with targets in the corners
Players line up with balls at the start
execution: Dribble through the cones at good speed
After the last cone, take 1-2 touches
Shoot on goal aiming for the corners
Jog to collect your ball
Repeat 5 times, then rest
coachingPoints: This drill makes you tired like in a real game
Focus on technique even when you're tired
Lift your head before shooting
Accuracy is more important than power
Great players can still finish when they're exhausted
visualDescription: Draw: Slalom pattern leading to goal

name: Rondo 4v1 Small
setup: Mark a small square, about 7x7 meters
Four players stand around the outside
One player (defender) goes in the middle
Start with one ball on the outside
execution: Four outside players keep possession by passing
Defender tries to win the ball or touch it
If defender touches the ball, they switch with who made the mistake
Count how many passes you complete
Challenge yourself to beat your record
coachingPoints: Make quick, accurate passes
Move to create passing angles for your teammates
If you're the defender, be patient and wait for mistakes
Communicate with your teammates
This teaches game awareness and quick thinking
visualDescription: Draw: Small square with 4 players outside, 1 defender inside

name: Rondo 5v2
setup: Make a circle about 10 meters wide
Five players stand around the outside
Two defenders work together in the middle
One ball starts on the outside
execution: Five players pass to keep possession
Two defenders work as a team to win the ball
If defenders win it, last two touches go in the middle
Try to make 10 passes in a row
Defenders should communicate with each other
coachingPoints: With two defenders, you need quick passing
Support your teammates by showing for the ball
Defenders should work together, not chase alone
This is harder than 4v1 - that's good
Stay positive and encourage each other
visualDescription: Draw: Larger square with 5 players outside, 2 defenders inside

name: Keep Ball in Zone
setup: Mark a rectangular zone, about 15x10 meters
Split into two teams (3v3 or 4v4 works well)
Both teams stay inside the zone
One team starts with the ball
execution: Team with ball tries to keep possession
Other team tries to win it back
Count consecutive passes out loud
When ball is won, counting starts over
Play for 2 minutes, then see which team passed more
coachingPoints: Move into space to help your teammates
Keep the ball moving with quick passes
If you lose the ball, work hard to win it back
Stay inside the zone no matter what
This is great practice for keeping the ball in games
visualDescription: Draw: Rectangular zone marked out

name: 2v2 + Joker (EXCLUSIVE)
setup: Create a square playing area, about 12x12 meters
2v2 in the middle - mark teams with different colors
Place 2 neutral players on opposite sides (jokers)
The jokers always help whoever has the ball
execution: Team in possession has a 4v2 advantage (2 + 2 jokers)
Try to make as many passes as possible
When the other team wins the ball, jokers switch to help them
Jokers can only play one-touch
Count passes and compete
coachingPoints: Use the jokers to help when you're under pressure
The team without the ball must work twice as hard
Jokers should always be ready to help
This teaches you to use extra players wisely
Very advanced drill - focus and communicate
visualDescription: Draw: 2v2 in center, neutral players on sides (EXCLUSIVE)

name: One-Touch Rondo
setup: Set up a square or circle, about 8x8 meters
4-5 players on the outside, 1-2 in the middle
Make the rule clear: only one touch allowed
Have an extra ball ready in case it goes out
execution: Pass the ball with only one touch
Defender tries to intercept or touch the ball
If you take two touches, you become the defender
This is very challenging - stay focused
Count passes to track improvement
coachingPoints: This is one of the hardest drills - be patient
Your first touch is also your pass
Position your body before the ball arrives
Look where you'll pass before you receive
Top players can do this - you can too with practice
visualDescription: Draw: Square with '1' indicating one-touch rule

name: Switch Zones Possession
setup: Mark two squares side by side, each about 10x10 meters
Split players into groups of 4-5 per zone
Each zone has defenders and attackers
Start with a ball in zone 1
execution: Keep possession in zone 1 with 4v2
When you hear 'switch', pass to zone 2
Team follows the ball to zone 2 and continues playing
Defenders sprint across too
Practice moving as a team
coachingPoints: Look for the right moment to switch zones
The switch pass needs to be accurate and strong
Move together as a team when switching
This teaches you how to switch play in real games
Communication is super important
visualDescription: Draw: 2 zones with arrow showing zone transition

name: T-Run
setup: Place cones in a T-shape: one vertical line and one horizontal
Make the vertical line 10 meters, horizontal 5 meters each way
Start at the bottom of the T
Show players the pattern before starting
execution: Sprint forward to the middle cone
Shuffle sideways to the right cone
Shuffle left all the way to the left cone
Shuffle right back to middle
Backpedal to the start - that's one rep
coachingPoints: Stay low when you shuffle sideways
Don't cross your feet when shuffling
Keep your chest facing forward
This trains movements you use in games
Push yourself but keep good form
visualDescription: Draw: T-shape made of cones

name: Shuttle 5-10-5
setup: Place 3 cones in a line: center, 5m left, 5m right
Start at the center cone
Make sure surface is safe for sprinting and turning
Have multiple lanes for team competition
execution: Sprint 5 meters to the right, touch the cone
Sprint 10 meters to the left cone, touch it
Sprint 5 meters back to center
Rest for 30 seconds
Repeat 3-5 times
coachingPoints: Touch the cone with your hand each time
Use quick, choppy steps to change direction
This builds agility for defending and attacking
Drive your arms to help you accelerate
This drill is tough but really effective
visualDescription: Draw: 3 lines showing 5m, 10m, 5m distances

name: Side Steps with Ball
setup: Mark two lines about 10 meters apart
Each player has a ball
Stand at one line facing sideways
Show proper form before starting
execution: Side-step to the other line while controlling the ball
Push the ball with the outside of your foot
When you reach the line, face the other way and return
Keep your body low and balanced
Do this 5 times each direction
coachingPoints: Keep the ball close during side movements
Use quick, small touches
This helps with shielding the ball in games
Stay on the balls of your feet
Defenders especially need this skill
visualDescription: Draw: Side-to-side arrows with ball

name: Sprint + Backpedal
setup: Mark a distance of 15-20 meters with cones
Players start at one end
Make sure the area is flat and safe
This drill is great for defenders
execution: Sprint forward to the far cone
Immediately turn and backpedal to the start
Keep your hips low when backpedaling
Repeat 6-8 times
Rest between reps
coachingPoints: Backpedaling is important for defenders
Stay on your toes when going backward
Don't turn your back - backpedal facing forward
Pump your arms even when going backward
This movement happens constantly in games
visualDescription: Draw: Forward arrow solid, backward arrow dotted

name: Cone Reaction Drill
setup: Place 4-5 cones in different colors around a center point
Each cone should be about 5 meters from center
Player stands in the middle
Coach needs to see all the cones
execution: Coach calls out a color
Player sprints to that colored cone and touches it
Sprint back to center and wait for next call
Coach varies the timing and colors
Do 10 sprints total
coachingPoints: React as fast as you can when you hear the color
This trains your brain and body together
Always return to center in a ready position
Football requires constant quick reactions
Stay focused even when you're tired
visualDescription: Draw: Multiple cones in different colors

name: Jump & Sprint (EXCLUSIVE)
setup: Set up a small hurdle or cone to jump over
Place a sprint cone 15 meters away
Have players start behind the hurdle
Make sure landing area is safe and clear
execution: Jump over the hurdle with both feet
Land and immediately sprint to the far cone
Walk back to recover
Repeat 8-10 times
Focus on quick transition from jump to sprint
coachingPoints: Explode up in your jump
Land softly with bent knees
Don't pause - sprint right after landing
This builds explosive power for the game
Professional athletes train like this
visualDescription: Draw: Small obstacle and sprint arrow (EXCLUSIVE)

name: GK Basic Handling
setup: Goalkeeper stands in goal or marked area
Coach or server stands 5-8 meters away with balls
Have plenty of balls ready
Start with gentle throws, then harder
execution: Server throws balls to different heights
Goalkeeper catches high balls above the head
Catch medium balls at chest height
Scoop low balls safely
Focus on proper catching technique every time
coachingPoints: Form a 'W' with your hands for high catches
Bring the ball into your chest after catching
Get your body behind the ball
Call 'keeper' so others know you're catching it
Good handling keeps your team safe
visualDescription: Draw: Goalkeeper with ball thrown from above

name: GK Short Distribution
setup: Goalkeeper starts with a ball in the goal area
Place two target players 10-15 meters away at angles
Mark where the targets should stand
Have several balls ready
execution: Goalkeeper rolls or throws ball to target 1
Target 1 passes back to the goalkeeper
Goalkeeper throws to target 2
Keep rotating between targets
Practice different types of throws
coachingPoints: Roll the ball on the ground for short passes
Throw overarm for longer distance
Always aim for your teammate's feet
Good distribution starts your team's attacks
Look before you throw to find open teammates
visualDescription: Draw: Goalkeeper with 2 target players

name: GK Dive Sides
setup: Goalkeeper stands in the center of the goal
Server stands 8-10 meters away
Use a soft surface if possible for safety
Start with gentle shots, increase difficulty
execution: Server shoots to the goalkeeper's left
Goalkeeper dives to make the save
Get up and reset to center
Server shoots to the right
Alternate sides for 10-15 saves total
coachingPoints: Take a small step toward the ball before diving
Extend your arms fully to reach
Land on your side, not flat on your stomach
Get up quickly like in a real game
Diving takes courage - be brave
visualDescription: Draw: Goalkeeper with left and right dive arrows

name: GK Footwork in Box
setup: Mark a small square in the goal area (about 4x4 meters)
Place 4 cones at the corners
Goalkeeper starts in the center
Coach stands outside with instructions
execution: Quick side steps to each cone
Forward and backward movements
Stay low in goalkeeper stance
Coach calls which cone to touch
Return to center after each movement
coachingPoints: Stay on the balls of your feet
Keep your hands ready to save
Good footwork helps you cover the goal
Quick feet = quick saves
Goalkeepers need to be fast in small spaces
visualDescription: Draw: Small square showing GK movement zone

name: 3v3 Mini Game
setup: Create a small field, about 20x15 meters
Set up two small goals or use cones
Make two teams of 3 players each
Decide on simple rules (kickoffs, throw-ins, etc.)
execution: Play a regular game with 3v3
First team to 3 goals wins
Everyone must touch the ball before scoring (optional rule)
No goalkeepers - everyone plays
Switch teams after each game
coachingPoints: In small games, everyone touches the ball a lot
Support your teammates by moving into space
Defend as a team, attack as a team
Small games teach you real football
Have fun and be creative
visualDescription: Draw: Small field with 3 player markers per team

name: Numbers Call Game
setup: Place a ball in the center of a square area
Put 4 cones in the corners
Assign each player a number (1, 2, 3, etc.)
Two teams stand at opposite corners
execution: Coach calls out a number
Players with that number sprint to win the ball
Try to score on the opposite goal
First to score wins that round
Coach can call multiple numbers for 2v2 or 3v3
coachingPoints: React quickly when your number is called
This trains your speed and reaction time
Be ready even when waiting
Compete hard but fairly
Celebrate your wins and learn from losses
visualDescription: Draw: 4 markers in corners, arrow to center

name: Chasing Player Tag
setup: Mark a circular or square area (about 20x20 meters)
Every player has their own ball
Choose one player to be 'it' to start
Stay inside the boundaries
execution: Everyone dribbles around the area
The player who is 'it' tries to tag someone
If you're tagged, you become 'it'
Keep dribbling while you play
If your ball goes out, you're automatically 'it'
coachingPoints: Keep your head up to avoid being tagged
Control your ball even when running away
This makes dribbling fun and competitive
Use your body to shield the ball
Laugh and enjoy this drill
visualDescription: Draw: Circle with chasing arrow

name: 2 Goals Transition (EXCLUSIVE)
setup: Create a field with a goal on each end
Two teams of 4-5 players each
Both goals are always active
Teams can score on either goal
execution: Team in possession attacks one goal
If they score or lose the ball, other team attacks opposite goal
Teams must transition quickly
This is very challenging and game-like
Play for 10 minutes, most goals wins
coachingPoints: When you win the ball, think attack immediately
When you lose the ball, think defend immediately
This is exactly like real games
Communication is critical
Very advanced - stay focused and work as a team
visualDescription: Draw: Field with goals on opposite sides (EXCLUSIVE)

name: Slow Ball Control Walk
setup: Mark a path or use the sideline
Each player has a ball
Walk in a line or spread out
This is a cooldown activity
execution: Walk slowly while gently touching the ball
Use very light touches to control it
Breathe deeply and relax
Take your time - no rushing
Walk for 5 minutes as you cool down
coachingPoints: This helps your body recover after hard work
Focus on soft touches
Let your heart rate come down gradually
Think about what you learned today
Recovery is important for getting better
visualDescription: Draw: Player walking slowly with ball

name: Partner Stretch
setup: Find a partner
Sit on the ground in a comfortable spot
Both players should know which muscles to stretch
Take turns helping each other
execution: Partner helps you stretch your hamstrings
Hold each stretch for 30 seconds
Switch legs and repeat
Then help your partner stretch
Try hamstrings, quads, calves, and hips
coachingPoints: Never stretch so hard it hurts
Gentle stretching prevents injuries
Talk to your partner about how it feels
Breathe slowly and relax
Stretching after training is very important
visualDescription: Draw: 2 players doing partner stretches

name: Breathing + Touches
setup: Find a quiet space on the field
Each player sits or stands with a ball
Get into a comfortable position
This is about calming down
execution: Take slow, deep breaths
Gently tap the ball with your feet
Breathe in for 4 seconds, out for 4 seconds
Keep making light touches on the ball
Focus on relaxing your whole body
coachingPoints: Your mind needs to recover too, not just your body
Deep breathing helps you calm down
Light ball touches keep you connected to the game
This is a peaceful end to training
Great players know how to relax
visualDescription: Draw: Lungs icon and ball

name: Core Plank 30s
setup: Find a clean, flat area
Everyone gets into plank position
Make sure everyone knows proper form
Have a timer or watch ready
execution: Get into plank position on your forearms
Keep your body in a straight line
Hold for 30 seconds
Rest for 30 seconds
Repeat 2-3 times to finish training
coachingPoints: Your core helps you with everything in football
Don't let your hips sag down
Breathe normally - don't hold your breath
If 30 seconds is too easy, go for 45 or 60
End every training with core work
visualDescription: Draw: Plank position icon
